title: Woodrow Wilson
deleted: Ross Kennedy writes that Wilson's support of segregation complied with predominant public opinion.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kennedy|first=Ross A.|title=A Companion to Woodrow Wilson|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TytaiSLySTsC&pg=PT171|year=2013|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|pages=171â€“174|isbn=978-1-118-44540-2}}</ref> [[A. Scott Berg]] argues Wilson accepted segregation as part of a policy to "promote racial progress... by shocking the social system as little as possible."<ref>Berg (2013), p. 306</ref> The ultimate result of this policy would be an unprecedented expansion of segregation within the federal bureaucracy; with fewer opportunities for employment and promotion open to African-Americans than before.<ref>"The Federal Government and Negro Workers Under President Woodrow Wilson", Maclaury, Judson (Historian for the U.S. Department of Labor)https://www.dol.gov/general/aboutdol/history/shfgpr00. Retrieved December 5, 2020.</ref> Historian Kendrick Clements argues that "Wilson had none of the crude, vicious racism of [[James K. Vardaman]] or [[Benjamin Tillman|Benjamin R. Tillman]], but he was insensitive to African-American feelings and aspirations."<ref>Clements (1992), p. 45</ref>
